63-59 West 49th Street, north side, east from Sixth Avenue.

709529f-a.text:
Sixth Ave., east side, north from, but not including West 48th Street.
February 1, 1929.

713334f-c.text:
(1)
72-38 West 48th Street, south side, east of Sixth Ave., as viewed across clearance for the R.K.O. Theatre, (formerly Roxy's, now (1937) TYw oeter). Note the Empire State Building in the background.
JMne 28, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
A view eastward from No. 52, (5-story brownstone building) and showing prominently Nos. 56-48, 42, and 40-38; 16 and 12- story building respectively; the larger of which is the Cellini Building.
July 23, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
A limited view, and showing mainly Nos. 64-70, a 17-story loft
Sailding.
July 23, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

West 48th Strect, north side, east from, but not including Sixth
Ave.
June 28, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, from a slight altitude, and showing the inside of lot which will be the site of the R.K.O. Theatre; now known (1937) as the
Center Theatre.
June 28, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
A view eastward from a point between 48th and 49th Streets, and showing demolition in the centre of block. Note the spire of the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas, and the rears of buildings as shewn
in No. 1.
June 14, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

709565f-c.text:
(1)
Sixth Ave., (not shown) between West 5Oth and 48th Streets and showing the future site of Radio City being cleared. Buildings shown on the right are on 48th Street, between Sixth and Fifth Aves; the parking lot includes the 49th Street side. Across the skyline (left to right) appears Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas, Grand Central Building, Chrysler Building, Fred. F. French Building, Chanin Building. Ruppert Building, Lincoln Building, Lefcourt National Building and 500 Fifth Ave. Building. In the foreground appears a portion of the few buildings left on the east side of Sixth Ave. and which today (1937)
still remain, Radio City being built around them.
September 14, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, and showing the 50th Street station of the Sixth Ave. Elevated Line. Building across the station roof is No. 1258 (old number.being 886) Sixth Ave., at the S.E. corner of 5Oth Street. This view shows on the left the three corners of Fifth Ave. and 49th Street,
through the clearance at the N.W. corner.
September 14, 1931.

709526f-b.text:
1220 to 123O Sixth Avenue, at adjoining and north of the N.E. corner of W. 48th Steet. All of these structures appear in View 1 whle No.2 shows only three, No's. 1220 to 1224. A.t the rear of these buildings the R.K.O. 9enter Theatre is being erected. The Sixth Avenue "El" line in April 1939 will have disappeared and the brownstone builoings at this site ready
for oemolition.
The New York Times of April 3, 1939 reports the immediate erection of a 20 story Roclefeller Center structure on this site, same cousummating this vast midtown comnercial and amusement
center w hich started in 1W31.
Occupancy is scheuuled for March 1, 1940. An interesting feature will be the overlapping of the new building at the 8th floor o the steel work of the Uenter Theatre. The theatre was
constructed with this provison in mind.
March 18, 1932
Views: 1-2

709525f-b.text:
1220 to 1236 Sixth Avenue, east side, north fro W. 48th to 49th Streets, showing a row of structures, several sligtly improved and the Center Theatre. The latter (No. 1236) is a part of Rockefeller City and is at the S.E. corner of 49th Street. This, a losing venture, may be demolished and an office structure erected
instead.
No. 2 shows the N.E. corner of 48th Street. The corner structure bears No's. 122O Sixth Avenue and 71 N. 48th Street. Adjoining same are two 4 story former private dwellings whose hnembers are 69 and 67. Overhead on the Avenus is the elevated line that shortly will be demolished in its antirety.
June 20, 1938.
Views 1 a nd 2
P. L. Sperr

709525f-a.text:

709527f-b.text:
Sixth Avenue, east side, north from W. 48th Street, showing prominently the excavation for the new Rodkefeller Center Buildfng. This is at the N. E. corner and is to be titled "the U. S. Rubber Co. Building." The enclosure is provided for the public who, as quite obvious, enjoy watching the foundation constructi mm. The publicity agent capitalized on this quirk and had the fence lettered "Sidewalk SSuperintendents Club". The insignia is titled, "De beste stuurlin staan an wal", whch translated is "The best nilots stand on the shore". This originated with the Netherlands Building, an adjolning Rockefeller
Center unit.
Views 1,2: July 18, 193'
View 3: June 21, 1939
P. L. Sperr

709542f-a.text:
(1) anc (2)
Sixth Avenue, east side, from West 49th (left) to 48th (right) Street's, showing mainly the row of structures at the N.E. corner of the latter point. These are to be demolished for a new Rockefeller Center unit which will be known as the U. S. Rubber Bilding. To the left. is the Center Theatre. The photographer is viewing southeastward from the opposite site of the Avende. Note the surface conditions upon same resulting
from subway construction underground.
Forming a backdrop are two office structures in the blocc below,one of which is on 48th Street and the
other on 47th Street.
View 1: May 6, 1939
View 2: June 21, 1939
P. L. Sperr
(3)
A more inclusive view from a vantage point above 49th Street. Note the Empire State Building in the
baokground.
View 3 June 21, 1939
P.L. Sperr

1507961-a.title: 48th Street (West) #123 - Sixth Avenue - Seventh Avenue, north side
1507961-a.folder: 48th Street (West) #123 - Sixth Avenue - Seventh Avenue, north side, Manhattan, NY

713335f-a.text:
(1)
48th Street, north side, east from but not including Sixth Ave. In the foreground, houses are being demolished for the construction of Rockefeller Centre. In the background may be seen the skyscraper at 444 Madison Ave. and, to its right, the new Waldorf-Astoria Hotel
nearing completion.
May 27, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, at a later date, further eastwaed and showing a closer
view of the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas.
March 28, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
Similar to No. 2, but at an earlier date.
October 18, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
